docs.lead_paragraph: Alexis Wan-Hua Chen, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lincoln C. Chen of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to Kyle Jamal Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul N. Johnson Jr. of Teaneck, N.J. The Rev. Thomas G. Cleveland, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Church with the Rev. Robert C. Alter, a Presbyterian minister who is the bride's great-uncle. The bride and bridegroom were until recently intern-teachers at Milton (Mass.) Academy. She taught dance, drama and health and he taught religion, ethics and community service.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your July 15 front-page article on how health maintenance organizations treat chronic and seriously ill patients is "balanced." But does such balance portray justice or reality?

headline.main: Rationed Health Care Serves the Bottom Line

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republicans, seeking to get a damaging A.F.L.-C.I.O. advertisement about Medicare off the air, are telling television stations that the advertisement is a lie and that broadcasting it may invite libel suits against them. The Republicans have a point. The advertisement may not lie, but it plainly exaggerates -- just not the way they say it does.

headline.main: Organized Labor Goes on the Offensive, and the Republicans Cry Foul

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate voted today to deny most Federal benefits and social services to legal immigrants who have yet to become citizens, and it blocked Democratic efforts to aid children in families who lose public assistance under a welfare bill moving swiftly through Congress. Senators also defeated a proposal that would have required the Secretary of Health and Human Services to study whether the legislation, if passed, causes an increase in poverty among children in the next two years. The proposal would have required the Secretary to suggest ways of halting any such increase.

headline.main: Senators Vote to Cut Off Benefits for Legal Aliens

docs.lead_paragraph: Following is an excerpt from remarks made by Speaker Newt Gingrich to a Blue Cross/Blue Shield conference on Oct. 24, 1995, in Washington. The words in boldface are broadcast in an A.F.L.-C.I.O. advertisement that Republicans are trying to persuade television stations not to run. Now let me talk a little bit about Medicare. Let me start at the vision level so you understand how radically different we are and why it's so hard for the press corps to cover us.

docs.lead_paragraph: A peripatetic couple, married for more than 56 years, who chose the city of romance to mark an 80th birthday. A prominent decorator prowling for antiques. A high school teacher who steered Joe Mantegna into acting. An 11-year-old exchange student from France who could not get his fill of pistachio ice cream. And 16 teen-agers from a French club in Montoursville, Pa., bent on what they hoped would be a memorable and merry adventure to the city of their dreams. Disaster, as is its wont, chose its victims mercilessly and indiscriminately when T.W.A. Flight 800 from Kennedy International Airport to Paris dropped out of the sky Wednesday night and sank into the sepulchral waters off the coast of Long Island. There is nothing but heartache when a plane crashes and the death toll equals with perfect precision the passenger list. That was the stark horror of T.W.A. Flight 800. None of the 230 aboard survived.

headline.main: Lives of Beauty and Business, Sports and Scholarship, Youth and Age

docs.lead_paragraph: The FHP International Corporation said yesterday that it planned to spin off the Talbert Medical Management Corporation, its physician practice management company, to shareholders. Talbert generates more than $450 million in annual revenues and serves more than 300,000 patients. Talbert would continue to serve FHP members after the spinoff, which is expected by the end of the year. FHP, based in Fountain Valley, Calif., said it planned to focus on its health maintenance organizations and insurance businesses. Shares of FHP rose $2.125, to $24.125, in Nasdaq trading.

headline.main: FHP INTERNATIONAL TO SPIN OFF MEDICAL MANAGEMENT UNIT

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George Pataki has rightly been blamed for much of the confusion in Albany that produced the latest budget of any state ever. But Mr. Pataki scored other achievements in the 1996 New York State legislative session that deserve notice. A Good Election Bill. For years, Albany has refused to remove the outrageous roadblocks that make it hard for candidates to get on the ballot, especially if they are challenging the party organization. The Republican State Senate has been most resistant to reform. Mr. Pataki took the lead in bringing the Senate around -- a little-noticed but important victory for the Governor.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the eve of a House vote, President Clinton today raised a dozen objections to a major Republican welfare bill and urged Congress to send him a bipartisan substitute that makes more modest cuts in future welfare spending. After suggesting last week that he might support the Republican bill, Mr. Clinton complained today that it would not insure health insurance for people forced off welfare rolls. Moreover, he said, "the bill makes deep cuts in the food stamp program," far exceeding the cuts he proposed, and provisions denying benefits to legal immigrants are "excessively harsh and uncompromising."

headline.main: President Says Cuts Are Too Deep in Republican Welfare Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: The House voted 238 to 184 today to retain a law that forbids Federal employee health plans to pay for abortion services except when a pregnant woman's life is at risk, or in cases of rape or incest. The vote was on an amendment, seeking to overturn the ban, to the 1997 spending bill for the Treasury Department, the United States Postal Service and the White House. The overall spending plan was later approved 215 to 207.

headline.main: House Retains Abortion Rule In Federal Jobs
